    cache:
        policy: push
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform validate
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME

"terraform tf lint":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    image:
        name: ghcr.io/terraform-linters/tflint:v0.58.1
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - tflint --init
        - tflint --recursive

"terraform tf fmt":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform fmt -recursive -check

"terraform plan":
    stage: terraform plan
    extends: .job_template
    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform plan -input=false -out="plan.cache"
        - apk --no-cache add jq
        - terraform show -json "plan.cache" | jq -r "( [.resource_changes[]?.change.actions?] | flatten) | { \"create\":(map(select(.==\"create\")) | length), \"update\":(map(select(.==\"update\")) | length), \"delete\":(map(select(.==\"delete\")) | length) }" > plan.json
    artifacts:
        name: plan
        paths:
            - "$TF_ROOT/plan.cache"
        reports:
            terraform:
                - "$TF_ROOT/plan.json"
    needs:
        - "terraform prepare"
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME

"terraform apply":
    stage: terraform apply
    extends: .job_template
    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN
    environment:
        action: start
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform apply -input=false "plan.cache"
    rules:
        - if: "$CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == $CI_DEFAULT_BRANCH"
          when: manual
    needs:
        - "terraform plan"
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    when: manual
    allow_failure: false

If you feel overwhelmed, that's ok üòÖ I try to explain the most important parts.

We are using the official terraform image therefore we have to do some standard customization in the .job_template by setting some terraform variables for managing the state hosted on GitLab.

But most important is the definition of our token:

    id_tokens:
        OIDC_TOKEN:
            aud: $CIS_TENANT_URL

The variable $OIDC_TOKEN is a predefined, short-lived JWT token that GitLab automatically generates for authenticating with OIDC providers. This is a secure method that avoids storing static secrets. In order to use it with our Cloud Identity Service we need to adjust the aud property (audience) and use the URL of our Cloud Identity Service Tenant.

Now all we need to take care of assigning the value of the OIDC_TOKEN to the environment variables needed by the btp and cloud foundry terraform providers. We do this on the job level and assign the value of the OIDC token to the environment variables read by the terraform providers:

    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN

4.3 Terraform provider setup

Now we "only" need to setup the terraform providers for btp and cloud foundry to ensure that they use the JWT token for authentication. This is done in terraform/prod/providers.tf

provider "btp" {
  globalaccount = var.globalaccount
  idp           = var.idp_origin_key
}

provider "cloudfoundry" {
  api_url = "https://api.cf.${var.cf_region}.hana.ondemand.com"
  origin  = var.idp_origin_key
}

4.4 Define Terraform Variables for prod environment in GitLab

The last step is to maintain the needed variables for the prod environment in GitLab.

Open your project on GitLab and go to Settings -> CI/CD -> Variables

Now you can maintain all needed terraform variables. Important if to always prefix them with TF_VAR_variable_name.

By making use of the environment and managing the main resources inside modules, are able to deploy all needed environments/stages per project by using just one GitLab project üöÄ.

This is the complete setup. Feel free to use it, adjust it, improve it, ... . I hope you learned something today and can benefit from the approach I am demonstrating here.

Outlook to our future approach

We want to follow our design principle that we have already successfully deployed in Google Cloud:

  • One central landing zone project which contains the overall global btp landscape and manages global trust, directories and subaccounts
    • The subaccount module will not only create the subaccount but also the "technical user" needed for the GitLab integration by utilizing the SAP Cloud Identity Provider Terraform Provider and assign this user to the appropriate role
    • In google cloud the creator of the project (=subaccount in btp), automatically became the owner of the project (full access). At the end of the project creation we always removed the landscaper user from the owner role to ensure that only the newly created project technical user is able to deploy ressources inside the project.
      We will try to setup the same approach in BTP. The landscape user should not be able to create any additional ressources inside a subaccount after the subaccount setup. This is the responsibility of the team working on the new project inside the subaccount.
  • Almost all platform users will only have viewer access to ensure that nobody does any changes by "accident". The terraform workflow sometimes takes a little longer compared to just a few clicks, but IaC brings you all the benefits compared to ClickOps
  • Every new BTP project will have one GitLab project for maintaining the infrastructure but also everything else needed for the project.
    • Right now we are migrating a CAP app from Google Cloud to SAP BTP (forced by the new license üôÑ)
    • The terraform code and the CAP source code are all managed in the same GitLab Project. One team member can take of provisioning the infrastructure, while another team member is adapting the CAP code. CAP app deployment will then also be done using the GitLab CI/CD pipeline (and of course automated tests upfront to ensure we did not break anything).

Questions?

Feel free to leave a comment or contact me directly here or via LinkedIn.

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2508
entry.content:
SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2508

With the launch of the new release 2508, this blog post delivers an in-depth overview of the newest features and improvements. The release has been available since August 16th, replacing the previous 2505 release. The highlights of the current release include: Support of CDS Table Entities as active persistence in RAP, SAP Fiori-based Multi-Dimensional Reporting or the new software delivery option for partners the "Add-On Product". 

The list of all new features can be found on the What's New for SAP BTP ABAP Environment page

All new AI features are summarized here.

ABAP Development Tools (ADT)

  • Creation of Behavior Definition for CDS Table Entities (see Table Entities and Creating Data Definitions)
  • New Icons for Fiori User Interface Editors (details)
  • Extensions to the Class and Interface: C1 Consistency and Compatibility Checks, the ATC checks API Release: Consistency of Released APIs and API Release: Compatibility of Released APIs now check for consistency and compatibility about BDEF-derived types in released classes and interfaces
  • ADT Debugger Comparison Tool for Internal Tables (details)
  • Enrichment in the Element Information Popup, you can now search for substrings within the structured display of the Element Information popup (see Editing ABAP Source Code and Analyzing CDS Objects)
  • Learning from the Key Bindings Toolbar and Highlighting Ghost Text at Keyword Completion In-Line (see Concepts: Keyword Completion and Tasks: Keyword Completion)
  • Display of Copyright Statement for ABAP Development Objects in Properties View
  • HTTP-based ADT Links for Form-Based Objects, until now, the HTTP-link support was available only for the source-code-based ABAP objects 
  • RAP Business Objects Test Double Framework: Auto-Fill CID Support for Modify EML Statement (details)
  • Working with Forms, you can create form templates using Adobe LiveCycle Designer directly in ABAP development tools for Eclipse. Form Templates can be retrieved during runtime via the class CL_FP_FORM_READER (details)
  • Working with Electronic Document Consistency Checks, you can now create and modify the consistency checks you want to perform on your business documents
  • Working with Electronic Document Consistency Representation Types, you can create and modify representation types for your business documents based on their source location. Configure these representation types within the Electronic Document Consistency framework to ensure consistency

Core Data Services

  • New CDS Views in Business Event Logging: C_BUEVLGEVTFULLPYLDJSONDEX_2: Business Event Data v2, C_BUSEVTLOGACTIVITYDEX: Business Event Activity,  C_BUSEVTLOGEVENTDEX_3: Business Event Header Data (v3)
  • Deprecated CDS Views in Business Event Logging: C_BUSEVTLOGEVENTDEX_2 (Business Event Header Data (v2) Use the following successor: C_BUSEVTLOGEVENTDEX_3 and C_BUEVLGEVTFULLPAYLOADJSONDEX (Business Event Data): Use the following successor: C_BUEVLGEVTFULLPYLDJSONDEX_2
  • CDS Hierarchy Generation Wizard, the wizard will derive potential hierarchy nodes already from the start (on the master data view) and guide you through the creation process

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)

  • Collaborative Draft, you can now add collaborative capabilities to your business object. The collaborative draft allows multiple users to work concurrently on the same draft instance (details)
  • Cross-BO Transactional Enablement, cross-BO scenarios can now be transactionally enabled by defining a cross-BO context for the respective BDEFs (see RAP-Operations for Associations and RAP-with Cross Associations and RAP-AssocImplType)
  • RAP Factory Actions, they now return the http status 201 instead of 200 in case of a successful OData V4 response

SAP Fiori

  • Fiori-Based Multi-Dimensional Reporting ‚Äì Cloud-Compliant, you need to quickly build an analytical Fiori application, but simple list reporting doesn‚Äôt satisfy your needs? Instead, you already built an analytical model with the new embedded analytics capabilities of the developer extensibility and now want to unleash its full potential? In that case, we have the right solution for you: Without writing a single line of additional code, you can simply expose your model in a full-fledged analytical application with a modern Fiori-based UI and real multi-dimensional ‚Äúslicing & dicing‚Äù capabilities
  • Fiori-Based Multi-Report Applications, you need to quickly build an analytical Fiori application, that puts multiple analytical queries into one context in a single UI? All you need to do is to provide the queries, bundle them in an InA Service and you are good to just start the brand new "Review Booklet Application" wizard to generate the application. Afterwards, you can refine the configuration of your Review Booklet in an easy to use Fiori UI
  • Fiori UIs for Communication Management Change History, it is now possible to view the communication management change history in Fiori UIs
  • Change Document Reuse UI, you can embed a reuse UI in your RAP OData V4 Fiori application (details)

Business Configuration 

  • Reduce Footprint with the existing RAP generator for business configuration maintenance objects, you can easily generate all development objects that are required for a configuration object. Since the number of objects is still quite large, optimizations in the RAP programming model have been implemented that reduce the number of required development objects and make them easier for a developer to manage 

Security

  • Business User Authentication, option for configuring secondary signing certificates, currently only basic authentication is supported as authentication for SMTP outbound communication. With this feature, also the OAuth Client Credential Grant will be supported

Business Events

  • Activate Business Event Logging, with this release, there are changes to the behavior of the configuration object. The option to select the logging of all data has been removed. By default, when you enable logging of data, all business event data will be recorded (details)
  • View Object Relationships, with this feature, you can view inbound and outbound relationships for logged objects in business event logging. You can also navigate across object components (details)
  • Log RAP-based C1 events, this feature enables the logging of C1-released, RAP-based events for local consumption (details)
  • Grouping Events as Activities, with this release, events of the same type and object occurring in the same session are grouped as activities. Sequences in the application Display Business Events by Objects are displayed according to activities. A new CDS view is also released to retrieve activity details. An activity is an action performed by a user or the system that initiates an event in the system (details) 
  • Expose Extensibility Status in Open Resource Discovery Document for Business Events, the Open Resource Discovery document for business events now exposes the extensibility status (details)
  • Success Log For Processed Events, it is now possible to configure a log for successfully processed events
  • Source Event Filter, you can now restrict the sending of events by defining filters for event topics. These filters can now also be created directly for event payload properties

Integration

  • Code Snippet in SOAP Service Consumption Model changed, the updated service consumption model improves the instantiation of consumer proxies and optimizes receiver determination through logical ports (details)

  • You can build and manage your own application interfaces in ABAP development tools for Eclipse (ADT) with the SAP Application Interface Framework (AIF). Due to the lack of ADT for AIF, the development objects for asynchronous integrations (event consumption model and asynchronous SOAP services) currently generate their corresponding AIF interfaces with default monitoring settings automatically. With new AIF development capabilities in ADT, these AIF interfaces can be customized. Custom AIF interfaces can also be created, for monitoring the background processing framework (bgPF) in ABAP Cloud, for example
  • The ABAP HTTP client and server now support server-sent events (SSE). Which allows a server to send parts of the body of the response to the client without the client having to actively request them. After being sent by the server, the client can fetch them as they become available (details)

Data Integration

  • Outbound SQL via CDS External Entities, the ADT generation wizard allows you to develop outbound SQL scenarios more efficiently by generating the required CDS external entities based on an imported CSN definition of the remote SQL API
  • SQL Service, INSERT and DELETE on Writable CDS View Entities, in data integration scenarios, users can access data in an ABAP system from an external consumer, using the SQL service and the ODBC driver for ABAP. So far, users can query data in exposed CDS view entities, and this was a read-only scenario, where SELECT statements could be used. Now, the SQL service can also be used to change data in exposed writable CDS view entities using INSERT and DELETE statements. Use cases for INSERT and DELETE in such a data integration scenario include: full replication of data from another system into the ABAP system or bringing data into staging tables that will be later used for your custom ABAP coding (details)

Reuse Services

  • Print Queue Administrator Integration, you can now create and delete print queues directly using APIs without the need to enter the Maintain Print Queues app. You can do so using the communication scenario SAP_COM_0A86 (details)

Background Processing Framework

  • Background processing is very important for business applications. A lot of logic can be executed asynchronously to improve performance. In scenarios where changes of the current LUW are to be communicated remotely, the asynchronous execution is even mandatory to be compliant with the SAP LUW (due to implicit database commits). We want to simplify and improve the background processing by covering all required qualities like: ‚Äúexactly once‚Äù, ‚Äúin order‚Äù, testability and an integration into the ADT cross trace for better supportability (details)

Technical Monitoring

  • SQL Statement Analysis app, with this app, you can analyze the performance and resource consumption of SQL statements within a selectable time range (details)

Lifecycle Management

  • Manage Software Components, the delete dialog for Bring Your Own Git has been modified. The Unregister repository checkbox within the dialog has been moved outside the dialog and changed to a separate Unregister button (see Delete Software Components and Bring Your Own Git)

Custom Code Migration App

  • Redesign of Fiori Space and Page Templates, the Custom Code Migration Fiori app has been split up into two separate tiles. There is now the Analyze Custom Code app for the custom code analysis use case and the Custom Code Migration app for the migration to SAP S/4HANA use case (details)

Landscape Portal

  • Delivery of an Add-On Product, if you have an SAP Partner Edge Build contract, you can now publish a product as an add-on product. This offers a second delivery option for partners as an alternative to the multitenancy SaaS solution. Your product will appear in the SAP Store, where eligible customers can install it in their own SAP BTP ABAP environment system. The Landscape Portal is used for both, to publish add-on products by partners, and to install them by the customers (details)

SAP Fiori Launchpad

  • Manage Launchpad Spaces and Pages: Redesign and Renaming, adapted overview pages to enhance working with spaces and space templates, as well as with pages and page templates. "Predefined" and "SAP-Delivered" were renamed to "Templates" to ensure consistent terminology between these apps (see Manage Launchpad Spaces and Manage Launchpad Pages)
  • New Layout for Launchpad Shell Bar and Menus (see User Menu, Shell and Shel Bar and Working with Notifications)

SAPUI5

  • Referenced SAPUI5 Version, as part of hotfix collection 4 (which is used for the standard upgrade), SAPUI5 version 1.136.4 is used for the administrator‚Äôs SAP Fiori launchpad, SAP-delivered Fiori apps, and the custom-built SAP Fiori apps, which are deployed to the ABAP system (see upgrade windows and SAPUI5)

entry.title: DSP SQL Navigator ‚Äì Stop copy pasting URLs!
entry.content:
I have been working with SAP Datasphere since 2019, back when it was still called SAP Data Warehouse Cloud (DWC). Obviously I have built my fair share of SQL views, and have been analyzing SQL views even more. That means a lot of jumping from one SQL view to another, which I do through copy-pasting the URL that I am currently on and changing it to the view I want to jump to. I must have copy-pasted hours on end since 2019 on a daily basis. But that is now behind me, and I will make sure you don‚Äôt have to anymore as well!

So like I wrote in the introduction, what I do to jump from one SQL view, to the view that lies beneath it is:

  • Copy the current URL
  • Copy the view name I want to jump into
  • Overwrite the last part of the URL with this view name.

I have always thought there must be a faster way to do this. With the upcoming of ‚Äúvibe-coding‚Äù and tools like Cursor and Claude Code, I finally tried to make my day a lot easier, by trying to code a browser extension.

Together with Claude I wrote a Product Requirement Document (PRD) and started working on the project together with Claude Code. Within a few hours the first useful version of the browser extension could be imported into my browser, and just a few hours later I had a polished version that I am now ready to share with you!

The plugin basically automated my old workflow. When you are in a SQL view and want to jump to the SQL view underneath that one, you simply select the view you want to jump to and press your hotkey and it open a new browser tab and open up that view for you!

Want to try it out? Basically all you have to do is download the plugin browser from the Google Web Store through this link. Then you have to assign a hotkey via the settings of the plugin and it works! You can also first check the demo if you want in this Youtube movie, where I show off the process! 

I am currently still working on the feature to jump to a view that is shared from another space, and will bring a new version of the plugin as soon as possible. If you have any questions please feel free to reach out to me!

entry.title: Everything You Need to Know About the SAP Young Professionals Program
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre an ambitious graduate looking to launch your tech consulting career, the SAP Young Professionals program might be the opportunity you‚Äôve been waiting for! This free, immersive training experience opens doors to become an SAP Associate Consultant and kick-start your career among SAP's. 

What is the SAP Young Professionals program?

It is a free, 2-3 month intensive training initiative from the SAP Digital Skills Center that aims to equip recent university graduates (with less than 3 years of graduation) with SAP knowledge, soft skills, and certifications that prepare them for SAP consulting-related position within the EMEA region. 

Graduates are trained in SAP technologies such as: SAP S/4HANA , SAP Analytics Cloud ,  Artificial Intelligence , SAP Business Technology Platform , within others ((Modules may vary by cohort or region).

Who is eligible for the program?

Applicants typically need to meet the following criteria.

  • Hold a university degree (Bachelor‚Äôs or higher). 
  • Be a recent graduate (within the past 3 years).
  • Be currently unemployed or underemployed
  • Show strong English proficiency.
  • Be citizens or legal residents of the country where the program is being offered.

Note: Specific requirements may vary depending on country and region.

What does the program include?

Over the course of 2‚Äì3 months, participants will:

  • Earn globally recognized certifications 
  • Gain access to SAP Learning Hub and be trained by SAP specialists 
  • Develop soft skills
  • Have the possibility of starting your career as Associate Consultant in SAP's ecosystem (partners + customers)

Is the program really free?

Yes. The SAP Digital Skills Center delivers this program at no cost to participants as part of SAP‚Äôs mission to close the digital skills gap and support sustainable employment. SAP invests in rising talent to help drive digital transformation across industries.

Is employment guaranteed after completing the program?

While job placement is not guaranteed, one of the key goals of YPP is to connect graduates with SAP partners and customers who are actively hiring. Many graduates secure employment within the SAP ecosystem shortly after completing the program. However, success depends on the graduate's performance, certification results, and engagement throughout the course.

How to apply?

Applications are submitted via üëâ  SAP Digital Skills Center portal.

Keep an eye on the website or SAP‚Äôs social media channels for announcements about new program cohorts in your region.

Written by Valentina Guevara.

entry.title: SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide: Essential Best Practices from Setup to Scale
entry.content:
The SAP BTP Guidance Framework is your compass towards architecting, developing, and operating solutions on SAP BTP. It is the central access point for decision guides, reference architectures, methodologies, recommendations and DevOps principles. IT guides developers, administrators, architects, and partners with best practices along their journey.

This blog post focuses on the SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide, which is a guided path for application development on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). As part of our blog series, we are diving into several topic areas to best help you navigate the framework. Refer to our first blog post for an introduction to the BTP Guidance Framework.

Who is the SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide for?

The SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide is embedded into the SAP BTP Guidance Framework and is dedicated to developers, architects, development project leads, and SAP partners. The guide supports each role to plan the application architecture, define the correct methodologies and tools, and select the right services. SAP partners can additionally use the guide to set up SAP BTP for developing and running applications and services for their customers.

What is it about?

The SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide explains the building blocks for developing, delivering, and running business applications following the design-led development phases. As development projects for business applications have similar characteristics, this guide condenses best practices and technologies that can be safely recommended to you. The goal of the guide is to support you along the development process as a standardized development guidance and to drive developer efficiency.

 

 

ExploreIdentify the business opportunity and set up the roles and responsibilities in your team.
DiscoverIdentify required use cases and understand the end user holistically. Get familiar with the available technology and get to know use case patterns that can be implemented using SAP BTP. Explore the set of tools and services that allow you to keep the pace when developing applications and at the same time benefit from future innovations in SAP BTP.
Design

Design the user experience of your application to provide good usability. Use domain-driven design to create an application that is modularized and has shorter innovation cycles and a clearer focus. Before you begin developing your applications, make sure your landscape setup is appropriate for managing their lifecycles.

DeliverDevelop your application by following the recommendations for the respective programming model (CAP & ABAP Cloud), programming languages, development tools and consider aspects such as multitenancy, security, extensibility and others.
Run & Scale Get constant feedback from your users, optimize the application based on their feedback, and operate the application using the services and capabilities SAP BTP offers.

What‚Äôs next? - Continuous Development

The SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide is a living document, and we are constantly updating and reassessing it. To get an overview about all the changes, we provide a dedicated page to show you what‚Äôs new for the BTP Developer's Guide in a comprehensive way.

The guide relies on your feedback which you can actively provide using GitHub. Prerequisite is that you are using the English version of the guide. Giving us feedback will get you in contact with the responsible authors of the SAP Help Portal pages and the development team to discuss documentation-related issues. To contribute to the BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide or to provide your feedback you have two options:

  • Click on Feedback > Create Issue: Provide feedback about a documentation page. This option opens an issue on GitHub.
  • Click on Feedback > Edit on GitHub: Contribute to a documentation page. This option opens a pull request on GitHub.

 

You can even comment directly in the guide when you have an SAP user and sign in.

To collaborate with us you can find more information here:

  • Contribution Guidelines
  • Introduction Video
  • Introduction Blog Post

With this we wish you successful application development.

For more resources explore the guidance framework or refer to the previous blog post: SAP BTP Guidance Framework Introduction. You can also stay tuned for the next blog post of the series covering Extensibility (will be linked as soon as possible).

Your SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide Team
